title: Episode 64 – Bethany Yarrow – Sacred Sound, Sacred Water
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[8.0s - 13.8s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.

[14.2s - 17.6s]: Today I am here visiting with Bethany Yaro.

[17.9s - 18.4s]: Hi Bethany.

[18.7s - 19.4s]: Hello Aaron.

[19.8s - 20.5s]: How are you doing today?

[20.9s - 21.8s]: I'm doing very well.

[22.0s - 22.4s]: How are you?

[22.7s - 23.4s]: Doing well.

[23.7s - 24.1s]: Doing well.

[24.3s - 25.5s]: So happy to be here with you.

[25.5s - 31.3s]: We're here in your home at the waterfall house in central New York, sitting by a very nice

[31.3s - 32.4s]: warm cozy fire.

[33.3s - 34.0s]: And it's just wonderful.

[34.5s - 36.4s]: Fireside chat in your best kind.

[37.0s - 38.0s]: Fireside chat.

[39.0s - 44.6s]: Yeah, so let me just share with our audience a little about you and your background.

[47.0s - 50.2s]: So Bethany Yaro sings music of power and praise.

[51.2s - 56.5s]: She is a songkeeper, earth activist and student of the spiritual traditions of the Americas.

[57.4s - 62.9s]: On stage she is a mesmerizing dancing spirit with a soulful voice and a living prayer for

[62.9s - 64.8s]: unity at the heart of her music.

[65.8s - 71.2s]: Bethany has been involved in many social justice, environmental justice and human rights issues

[71.2s - 72.2s]: throughout her life.

[72.9s - 78.6s]: In her role as a musician activist, she often finds herself in the streets playing at

[78.6s - 81.5s]: demonstrations, rallies and concerts for change.

[82.8s - 88.9s]: Bethany has worked on native, non-native alliance building for over a decade, was one of the

[88.9s - 95.1s]: founding organizers of the Black Hills Unity concert, as well as the Waterfall Unity Alliance,

[95.4s - 100.6s]: which was formed to stop pipelines and fossil fuel infrastructure expansion in New York,

[101.1s - 105.0s]: and to transition to earth-based models of community power.

[105.7s - 112.0s]: She is also a member of the advisory board of the Center for Earth Ethics at Union Theological

[112.0s - 112.6s]: Seminary.

[113.6s - 119.5s]: As the daughter of Peter Yaro of Peter Paul and Mary, Bethany carries a legacy of music

[119.5s - 121.4s]: and activism across the generations.

[122.2s - 129.8s]: The first time she was arrested was with her dad in 1986 when she was 14 protesting apartheid

[129.8s - 133.9s]: and singing We Shall Overcome in front of the South African Embassy.

[135.7s - 141.0s]: Musicly Bethany is best known as one half of the dynamic duo Bethany and Rufus that she

[141.0s - 146.2s]: formed with groundbreaking cellist Rufus Capodotia in 2001.

[147.9s - 153.0s]: Although Bethany put filmmaking aside many years ago, she revisited her cinematic roots

[153.0s - 159.0s]: to help with the filming of the feature documentary The Grandmother Speak for the next seven

[159.0s - 164.2s]: generations, a film about the Council of the 13 Indigenous Grandmothers.

[165.0s - 169.9s]: So Bethany, thanks for welcoming me to your home and welcome to the podcast.

[170.3s - 171.1s]: Thank you so much.

[171.9s - 174.2s]: Well, you know, I'm so excited to dive in.

[174.3s - 179.5s]: We've got a lot to talk about, and I just can't help but ask, you know, you don't often

[179.5s - 184.3s]: introduce somebody by saying the first time she got arrested, right?

[184.3s - 189.4s]: So maybe you could share a little with us about that part of your background and the work

[189.4s - 190.2s]: you've been doing.

[190.6s - 193.3s]: In terms of arrest, the rest of being in arrestable?

[193.7s - 195.7s]: Yeah, being in arrestable in terms of your activism.

[198.3s - 208.6s]: Well, you know, I clearly grew up with a sense of urgency around change human rights,

[211.2s - 220.5s]: enormous agency of, well, for my dad, I guess it was his ethical, cultural Jewish roots

[220.5s - 226.0s]: of Takoon Alam, you know, it's not up to me to change the whole world, but it's up to

[226.0s - 228.2s]: me to do my part in what I can do.

[229.0s - 239.1s]: So I've always been very aware of privilege and how to use any measure of privilege that

[239.1s - 243.9s]: you can as a level, lever for positive social change.

[244.5s - 247.8s]: And privilege really meaning all the gifts that you've been given.

[249.6s - 255.9s]: You know, however, you manifest those gifts in your life, but that we're really here

[255.9s - 260.4s]: to help make the world a better place and to leave it better than we found it.

[260.7s - 269.1s]: And just deep caring and compassion around what goes on in the world and that we are all

[269.1s - 269.7s]: related.

[270.1s - 272.6s]: I mean, that was always really a part of my upbringing.

[275.4s - 281.0s]: So I was active early on when I was in high school around the anti-apartheid movement.

[284.5s - 287.7s]: And Bishop Tutu had just gotten the Nobel Peace Prize.

[288.3s - 293.2s]: And so we were all down in Washington, D.C. and there was a big rally.

[293.7s - 296.5s]: And then Peter Paul and Mary were all going to go get arrested.

[298.7s - 302.3s]: And I begged my dad, I said, please, I want to get arrested with you.

[303.3s - 305.2s]: And he jokes about it.

[305.3s - 310.0s]: And he says, you know, his mom was a school teacher for 30 years in New York City Public

[310.0s - 310.4s]: Schools.

[310.8s - 314.1s]: And so he was like, no, you can't miss two days of school.

[314.4s - 319.7s]: I mean, that was, you know, much, but I begged, anyway, he let me get arrested with him.

[319.7s - 326.0s]: And so that was the first time where I, the sense of civil disobedience and putting yourself

[326.0s - 326.8s]: on the line.

[328.3s - 334.2s]: That is a part, very much a part of social change and very much a part of what people are

[334.2s - 341.2s]: doing, you know, right now in terms of massive civil disobedience all over the world right

[341.2s - 341.6s]: now.

[342.7s - 350.4s]: But here in the United States, you know, around the protest of immigration, the climate

[350.4s - 357.4s]: change, the kids extinction rebellion, you know, but country after country after country

[357.4s - 363.4s]: right now, people are starting to stand up and find a collective voice of power and

[363.4s - 368.9s]: say these systems no longer serve us and are destroying the planet, are destroying our

[368.9s - 374.0s]: cultures, are destroying what we have left that's good and we need to change.

[374.3s - 375.4s]: Yeah, absolutely.

[376.5s - 383.1s]: Well, and I know you were very involved with the youth and indigenous climate marks that

[383.1s - 385.9s]: took place in New York in September of 2019.

[387.3s - 392.0s]: And in fact, that's how we met, which was beautiful right around that time.

[393.2s - 397.3s]: And I know that you're also working with a number of indigenous communities.

[397.3s - 403.1s]: Which was the Friday's for future march because in September of 2014, you know, it was the

[403.1s - 408.5s]: big climate march in mobilization where there were 400,000 people in the streets.

[408.5s - 408.9s]: Yeah.

[409.4s - 413.2s]: This one was September 20th.

[413.2s - 421.3s]: And it was really led by the children, by the Friday's for future coalition and many

[421.3s - 429.5s]: other, you know, allied groups, zero hour and then there are a lot of them.

[431.2s - 436.1s]: So that was when Greta Tunberg came and helped lead that march.

[436.9s - 437.1s]: Yeah.

[437.1s - 437.9s]: That's when we met.

[438.0s - 438.3s]: That's right.

[438.5s - 439.0s]: That's when we met.

[439.0s - 442.9s]: There are many key September climate marches in my world.

[443.0s - 447.2s]: So just keeping, you know, being clear.

[447.2s - 447.6s]: Being clear.

[448.3s - 448.5s]: Yeah.

[448.8s - 450.6s]: Well, well, articulate that's beautiful.

[451.5s - 458.9s]: And at around that same time, we had the opportunity to come together at Union Theological

[458.9s - 462.7s]: Seminary for a very special event related to water and healing.

[462.7s - 470.4s]: And this included, of course, the Center for Earth Ethics and the Ecopiece Middle East

[470.4s - 470.9s]: leaders.

[471.4s - 478.3s]: And could you tell us a little about what happened there at that gathering and why was that important?

[480.7s - 487.0s]: Well, I kind of feel like at that gathering, many different lines came together for me personally.

[488.5s - 496.1s]: I've been a water activist and really have been standing behind the prayer of the water

[497.6s - 500.4s]: for about 10 years now.

[503.2s - 512.3s]: And of course, I have my Jewish ancestry from my father's side and I have my Irish Swedish

[512.3s - 519.6s]: Norwegian German Catholic Lutheran ancestry from my mother's side.

[519.7s - 520.5s]: She's from Minnesota.

[522.2s - 529.1s]: And then it's the alliance work that I've been working on for a long time between native

[529.1s - 537.5s]: and non-native communities around reparations, social justice, environmental justice, climate

[537.5s - 538.1s]: issues.

[539.1s - 546.1s]: So, Chief Perry was there doing Perry of the Ramippo Lennopination, which are the original

[546.1s - 547.2s]: people of New York City.

[548.5s - 559.6s]: So and I have been working with a Ramippo ever since 2016 when we formed a Solidarity

[559.6s - 563.3s]: protest camp with Standing Rock at the time.

[563.3s - 570.5s]: And also to protest the AIM pipeline, the Angong Kuan pipeline, that was a gas pipeline

[570.5s - 579.2s]: that now passes right within 100 feet of the Indian point, nuclear power plant right outside

[579.2s - 579.8s]: of New York City.

[580.2s - 586.9s]: So just kind of protesting the insanity of what these pipelines are, the location, the

[586.9s - 590.7s]: destructive, extremely destructive nature of them.

[591.8s - 597.6s]: So, it was all of these different people coming together and there was water from the Jordan

[597.6s - 604.9s]: River that they had brought and water from the Hudson River that was brought and mixed

[604.9s - 606.5s]: together and a prayer was said.

[608.6s - 612.6s]: But the Jordan River, my dad wrote a song called the River of Jordan.

[613.0s - 620.3s]: You know, the mythical biblical river of Jordan, these baptismal waters, these waters

[620.3s - 621.1s]: of spirit.

[621.5s - 628.0s]: And I think a lot of people don't know that the Jordan River is now polluted and drying

[628.0s - 635.8s]: up, that the sea of Galilee is now drying up, that the water is disappearing from the region

[635.8s - 642.6s]: and what water is left in one of the driest areas of the world is contaminated and polluted.

[643.4s - 653.0s]: So in the ways that I've been taught and in ways that I believe, you know, water is really

[653.0s - 660.0s]: a living being and it has a spirit and it's a very powerful spirit of healing and of life

[660.0s - 660.7s]: literally.

[662.8s - 669.6s]: We know we're made of water, our bodies are part of the water, the moon affects our bodies,

[669.6s - 671.8s]: like it affects the tides of the water.

[672.0s - 676.4s]: We're very much a part of this living spirit of water.

[677.3s - 682.6s]: And so bringing these waters together, making a prayer for unity, making a prayer for

[682.6s - 690.0s]: coming together, making a prayer for our earth, of these different lines, indigenous earth

[690.0s - 698.0s]: based lines, Jewish lines, Christ, you know, root based lines.

[699.6s - 704.6s]: For me really that's the key to healing right now.

[705.5s - 708.5s]: My brother always says to me, we're the generation here to heal.

[709.0s - 709.8s]: Oh, I love this.

[709.9s - 711.7s]: And that is our role.

[712.3s - 716.8s]: So with all of the lines that are in me and then all of the alliances that I've been

[716.8s - 725.6s]: working on for so long, this is our time not just to work side by side but to really

[725.6s - 731.7s]: join hands, understand that we are all related, that we are all indigenous to this earth in

[731.7s - 739.9s]: some way and to return to understanding, honoring, respecting and restoring the earth who

[739.9s - 744.2s]: is, you know, the mother of us all and the water who gives us life.

[745.2s - 751.6s]: So that was kind of the context of that, the prayer, the song and what was being done

[752.6s - 756.3s]: at Union Theological Seminary with the Center for Earth Ethics.

[756.4s - 763.4s]: Yeah, it was such a magical, beautiful gathering ceremony and then walking for, I don't know

[763.4s - 769.6s]: how many blocks to get down to the Hudson River where the water was poured in from the

[769.6s - 774.0s]: Jordan that had been mixed into the ceremonial vessel.

[774.9s - 780.0s]: And I think as a treat for our audience, we'll probably be able to add at the end of our

[780.0s - 788.8s]: conversation here a few minutes of you singing Bethany at the ceremony and I'll admit I was

[788.8s - 791.9s]: just holding the camera on my phone by hand.

[791.9s - 797.0s]: So it's a little shaky but you'll get a sense of the audio and some of the beautiful echoes

[797.0s - 804.2s]: in the chapel where we were and get hopefully a feel for some of the beauty and the love

[804.2s - 809.0s]: and the healing energy that was activated and live in there that day.

[810.0s - 817.5s]: And to have those folks from Ecopiece Middle East, from Jordan, from Palestine and from

[817.5s - 824.8s]: Israel all coming together was also just a tremendous moment in gesture of what we humans

[824.8s - 827.8s]: are capable of when we're leading with love.

[828.6s - 835.8s]: Yeah and the way that they work also, at least as I understand, I know very little about

[835.8s - 839.8s]: Ecopiece Middle East except for that gathering but what they were talking about which was

[839.8s - 843.8s]: very moving for me was using the waters of bridge between cultures.

[844.3s - 851.8s]: So Jordanians, Israelis, Palestinians, all of them are all relying on this water.

[852.4s - 860.8s]: So how can we use this ecological necessity as a way of coming together?

[861.1s - 865.6s]: I mean kind of like what I'm near way, I'll get to this but on the same way.

[866.0s - 867.2s]: I was just about to say that.

[867.3s - 876.7s]: The work that we're doing up here, I mean I am clearly, you know, pretty far left in

[876.9s - 886.7s]: a lot of the ways that I think and conceive pretty solidly not in line with the Neal

[886.7s - 896.8s]: liberal model, with our economic models, not necessarily at all supportive of our governmental

[896.8s - 902.6s]: structures as they're being revealed right now in terms of the corruption and the corporate

[902.6s - 903.6s]: reality.

[904.1s - 910.5s]: I just find it incredibly destructive, the consumerism, the way out so much.

[911.8s - 925.8s]: And where I live here is in a very rural community that is a very Republican, red, Trump supporting

[925.8s - 927.1s]: area.

[928.7s - 931.8s]: You know, people talk about the deep south.

[931.9s - 936.5s]: This is kind of like a version of like the deep north in that way.

[938.9s - 949.0s]: And I've never felt so hopeful here about building alliances, finding common ground, finding

[949.0s - 956.4s]: ways to talk because most of the people up here are in the forests, are 100% understand

[956.4s - 964.2s]: the earth and have a deep respect for mother nature, have a deep respect for the spirits

[964.2s - 970.1s]: of the forest and the animals, you know, and it's not that people who are really from here,

[970.3s - 976.9s]: a lot of them have mohawk ancestry, a lot of them, you know, they really are very much connected

[976.9s - 983.9s]: to the land and really want to preserve the wildlife, the water, the trees, the forests.

[983.9s - 987.7s]: It's not an exploitative mindset.

[988.6s - 994.6s]: So I mean, I've found that there's, and there are a lot of farmers who really recognize

[995.1s - 999.1s]: that, you know, they look at what just happened in the Midwest to the farms there and the floods

[999.1s - 999.8s]: that are happening.

[1000.0s - 1004.1s]: They understand the seasons are changing, that the climate is changing.

[1004.6s - 1011.5s]: Even at the same time, there's a lot of climate denial around causation or, you know, the

[1011.5s - 1017.4s]: root causes or there is definitely an understanding of this is happening.

[1017.8s - 1025.8s]: So how do we come together now with whatever tools we have to solve problems and to build

[1025.8s - 1026.2s]: community?

[1026.7s - 1026.8s]: Yep.

[1027.2s - 1028.4s]: I mean, that's where we are.

[1028.6s - 1036.5s]: And there's been an incredible amount of just welcoming a lot of dialogue, a lot of

[1036.5s - 1041.4s]: let's roll up our sleeves and make this happen and let's vision a different way of living

[1041.4s - 1041.9s]: together.

[1042.7s - 1047.5s]: You know, every, I think everyone up here really recognized that government as it is is

[1047.5s - 1048.0s]: not working.

[1048.4s - 1052.4s]: And we have many different reasons why we think that and my reasons might be very different,

[1052.9s - 1056.4s]: you know, and solutions also might seem to be very different.

[1056.9s - 1060.3s]: But if you can come up with a really different vision of how to live together and protect

[1060.3s - 1067.3s]: the land, everybody's coming on board in a beautiful way that's not partisan and is

[1067.3s - 1068.4s]: really healing divides.

[1068.9s - 1069.0s]: Yep.

[1070.2s - 1071.5s]: Well, it's actually beautiful.

[1071.9s - 1078.4s]: You know, I've had the opportunity to spend several days here with you at this amazing

[1078.4s - 1085.1s]: place in home that you call the waterfall house, which is perched on up above a waterfall.

[1085.1s - 1090.0s]: And there is some very special beautiful water flowing right through here.

[1090.7s - 1096.6s]: And this is the place where the Three Sisters Sovereignty project is launching now.

[1096.8s - 1104.7s]: And it's just an utter joy to see what's happening here and how you are sharing your gifts

[1104.7s - 1112.2s]: and resources to help this whole thing sprout and come alive right here in these ancestral

[1112.8s - 1114.4s]: lands of the Mohawk people.

[1115.4s - 1120.9s]: And I'm wondering if you might share a little with our audience about what waterfall house

[1120.9s - 1126.1s]: means to you and symbolizes and what's happening with the Three Sisters Sovereignty project.

[1126.4s - 1128.5s]: That's such a big question.

[1129.9s - 1134.2s]: Well, this is, I'm for the most part born and raised in New York City.

[1136.8s - 1145.0s]: So I came up here about 20 years ago and as much as I found the waterfall, the waterfall

[1145.0s - 1146.9s]: found me, you know.

[1147.7s - 1155.2s]: And in buying this land and this property and starting to care take for this waterfall,

[1155.9s - 1159.5s]: my own life began to change.

[1161.2s - 1165.6s]: And there were many things in my life that changed around that time.

[1166.9s - 1171.2s]: But it was the first time that I really connected to the land.

[1172.8s - 1178.9s]: And I started care taking and there was something larger than myself that was at work.

[1179.9s - 1189.0s]: There's definitely a spirit here that you're as much, you know, in service too as anything else.

[1191.1s - 1199.5s]: So they call this waterfall, the original name of it is something like Ghanenwurigata or something like that.

[1200.1s - 1208.9s]: But even the Mohawks that I've spoken to, it's like a bad translation from the 1700s of what the old Mohawk

[1208.9s - 1214.2s]: was. So there's been a bit of delving into what the meaning might be.

[1216.9s - 1223.9s]: And one of the meanings that one of the elders up from Aquasasne said is that it's like the one you can hear,

[1224.3s - 1225.4s]: the one that talks loudly.

[1226.1s - 1229.6s]: So you can definitely hear it from most places on the property.

[1229.8s - 1235.3s]: But it also talks very loudly to people and that gives people instructions.

[1235.3s - 1243.6s]: And I've seen people go through an incredible transformation because it's still a wild river and the forest are still wild.

[1244.4s - 1249.2s]: And so there's something of like returning to your human beingness that happens.

[1250.0s - 1258.8s]: And they say that trauma, one of the definitions of trauma, is the places where of disconnection.

[1258.8s - 1260.6s]: You know where you really disconnect.

[1261.1s - 1267.1s]: And I understand, especially in terms of the way that we live in the world right now,

[1267.6s - 1275.1s]: and the world is really a place designed right now for disconnection, for atomization, for walking around like this.

[1275.3s - 1278.7s]: There's, we live in a space of disconnection for the most part.

[1278.9s - 1285.1s]: In America here, many places of the world, the so-called civilized first world,

[1285.1s - 1291.9s]: is also a place of this kind of trauma of disconnection.

[1292.2s - 1297.3s]: From your roots, from the land, from family, from, so, and the way to heal,

[1297.4s - 1299.4s]: trauma is through connection.

[1301.4s - 1308.2s]: And so I've just seen people go through these incredible processes of the human here.

[1309.2s - 1321.1s]: And one of the most profound processes of healing that I've seen is working with different mohawk relatives as they come back to this land,

[1321.4s - 1325.1s]: which are their ancestral lands where many of them have not been here.

[1325.3s - 1333.4s]: It's always been this story, you know, that they've heard of, oh, how things were before, the lands that were taken from us.

[1333.4s - 1340.6s]: And to come back to the land, to come back to the waterfall, to come back and be welcomed,

[1341.1s - 1344.8s]: and to feel, again, like the land is welcoming them back.

[1346.9s - 1353.9s]: There's an enormous amount of healing in that, and an acknowledgement that even the trauma happened,

[1353.9s - 1360.4s]: that there is an original wound all over Turtle Island, all over this continent, this country,

[1361.7s - 1370.7s]: that for so long has just been un-enknowledged, you know, the whole campaign of indigenous people of Native Americans,

[1370.7s - 1371.9s]: of we are still here.

[1372.5s - 1375.8s]: You know, we are not your mascot, we are not a Halloween costume.

[1376.4s - 1386.3s]: This is not something that happened before, this is still happening, the destruction, the trail of tears, the decimation of culture.

[1386.3s - 1392.9s]: This is happening right now, it's happening that, you know, uranium poisoning in the black hills,

[1393.1s - 1398.7s]: where they're doing uranium mining, and all over the reservations there are people with cancer or uranium.

[1399.3s - 1404.0s]: The life expectancy on Pine Ridge and adult male is 48 years old.

[1405.1s - 1410.3s]: Cancer, diabetes, all through the roof, up in aquasusney, Mohawk reserve,

[1410.3s - 1418.2s]: it's the largest PCB dump in America, cancer, diabetes, child, cancer rates, through the roof.

[1418.8s - 1425.2s]: The Ramapoh Ford Motor Company dumped all their lead paint into their water supply.

[1425.6s - 1428.1s]: They've lost a third of their population in Ringwood.

[1428.3s - 1433.2s]: I mean, this is all still happening, it's like a different version of the smallpox blankets.

[1434.2s - 1452.9s]: That are these gifts to the community, you know, of the legacy that us, the settlers, and our consumer ways and our mindset have been a disease that have really infected and destroyed communities and continues to do that.

[1452.9s - 1466.4s]: So, within the conversation of reparation and what is possible, and how can we envision a different future, and also privilege and all of these things,

[1466.9s - 1473.0s]: you know, I look around at what I've lived my whole life, my education that I've had, you know, I really say,

[1473.0s - 1478.4s]: if I can't do this with everything I have here, then who is going to?

[1478.8s - 1488.7s]: If I'm not going to be the one to kind of stand up, make mistakes along the way, you know, really see what is possible in terms of making relations,

[1489.8s - 1500.3s]: helping to manifest a different community, helping to bring people together in this way, giving what I have, the excess that I don't need,

[1500.3s - 1505.0s]: that, you know, what is it to really live simply, so that others can simply live?

[1505.2s - 1514.9s]: What is that? How do you actually live that motto, and that doesn't just mean, you know, buying one less iPhone, you know, there's,

[1514.9s - 1529.3s]: and I was just actually at the Carter Center talking to people then, and it was a donors, you know, there are a lot of people who donate to the Carter Center

And just deep caring and compassion around what goes on in the world and that we are all

That is a part, very much a part of social change and very much a part of what people are

Being clear.

You know, the mythical biblical river of Jordan, these baptismal waters, these waters

So in the ways that I've been taught and in ways that I believe, you know, water is really

We know we're made of water, our bodies are part of the water, the moon affects our bodies,

Oh, I love this.

So with all of the lines that are in me and then all of the alliances that I've been

Well, it's actually beautiful.

And in buying this land and this property and starting to care take for this waterfall,

You know where you really disconnect.

There's, we live in a space of disconnection for the most part.
In America here, many places of the world, the so-called civilized first world,

From your roots, from the land, from family, from, so, and the way to heal,

And so I've just seen people go through these incredible processes of the human here.

There's an enormous amount of healing in that, and an acknowledgement that even the trauma happened,

You know, we are not your mascot, we are not a Halloween costume.

This is happening right now, it's happening that, you know, uranium poisoning in the black hills,

The life expectancy on Pine Ridge and adult male is 48 years old.
Cancer, diabetes, all through the roof, up in aquasusney, Mohawk reserve,

The Ramapoh Ford Motor Company dumped all their lead paint into their water supply.
They've lost a third of their population in Ringwood.
I mean, this is all still happening, it's like a different version of the smallpox blankets.

That are these gifts to the community, you know, of the legacy that us, the settlers, and our consumer ways and our mindset have been a disease that have really infected and destroyed communities and continues to do that.
So, within the conversation of reparation and what is possible, and how can we envision a different future, and also privilege and all of these things,
you know, I look around at what I've lived my whole life, my education that I've had, you know, I really say,
if I can't do this with everything I have here, then who is going to?

that, you know, what is it to really live simply, so that others can simply live?
What is that? How do you actually live that motto, and that doesn't just mean, you know, buying one less iPhone, you know, there's,
and I was just actually at the Carter Center talking to people then, and it was a donors, you know, there are a lot of people who donate to the Carter Center
and all the wonderful work that the Carter Center, Jimmy Carter's organization is doing, and I, and it was also on the eve of the Fridays for Future Strikes,
where all of the kids were standing up, and my daughter is one of the strikers as well, she's been striking since March,

the most selfish thing you can do is to be generous, the most selfish thing you can do is to give everything you have,

at this moment in transition, it's just us, there's nobody else coming, and we're at a pivotal time of change.
I love this, well, it's just us and we're in it together.
That's all we got, it's just you and me, and you know, and on all of our relations and all the people coming together,
and it's not easy, it's not easy to forge a new way, it's not easy to manifest a new vision, it's not easy to have the humility and the courage to make mistakes.
And we're going to make mistakes, and then so how do you have the grace to forgive and keep moving, and be able to shift course and change and take the best?
